unit_learning_outcomes.description: Explain the multi-factorial nature of health and disease.
Apply an understanding of the epidemiological aspects of disease, to issues such as immunisation, infection control and disease prevention.
Demonstrate a broad knowledge and understanding of medical microbiology and general pathological processes.
Demonstrate the appropriate use of terminology, within the disciplines of pathology and microbiology.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: 3 hours per week self-instructional learning, readings from the text and exercises on lecture topics

enrolment_rules.description: 20cp from ANAT1001 or HLTH108 or BIOL1110 or BIOL115 or BIOL1210 or BIOL108

assessments.description: Two online lab quizzes and one online lab procedures test
11 short quizzes completed over the semester during online tutorial classes.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.subject_search_title: HLTH2301 - Principles in Health and Disease 1
data.description: This unit provides the students with the opportunity to explore the relationship between health and disease, from both the biological and psychosocial perspective. The diversity of stressors influencing the human body and mind is explored, and the response of the body to them is discussed. This includes adaptations at both cellular and tissue levels of organisation, inflammation, the immune response, tissue death and neoplasia. The immunisation debate and other relevant public health issues are explored. The relationship between the brain, 'mind', immune and endocrine systems is also studied. By the conclusion of this unit, students will have an understanding of the complex relationship between ourselves and our environment.
